---
Transcription-wide Association Studies (TWAS) are a class of analytical methods that aim to understand the relationship between genetic variants and human diseases by examining perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These approaches have been successful in several areas, including elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. With the abundance of gene expression data across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], TWAS offers a valuable tool for identifying disease-associated biological processes by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings. Nevertheless, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, which may overlook more intricate interactions at the network level.

In summary, while TWAS has proven to be a powerful method for identifying disease-associated genetic variants and their downstream effects on gene expression, its reliance on individual gene analysis may limit its ability to capture complex interactions at the network level. This knowledge gap highlights the need for further research into more sophisticated analytical methods that can account for such interactions, thereby enhancing our understanding of the genetic basis of human diseases.

Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) are a powerful tool in the field of functional genomics, as they test whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms underlie the association between genetic variants and human diseases [[doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482](http://doi.10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482); [doi:10.1038/ng.3506](http://doi.10.1038/ng.3506); [doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889](http://doi.1371/journal.pgen.1007889); [doi:10.1038/ng.3367](http://doi.10.1038/ng.3367)]. These approaches have been successful in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level [[pmid:33931583](http://pmid:33931583); [doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225](http://doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225); [pmid:31036433](http://pmid:31036433)] and have further shown promise in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [[doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w]](https://doi.org/10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w)] and drug repurposing tasks [[doi:10.1038/nn.4618]](http://doi.10.1038/nn.4618)]. Given the abundance of gene expression data across various tissues [[doi:10.1038/nbt.3838](http://doi.10.1038/nbt.3838); [doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6)](https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6)], [;](http://doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776) [[doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9)](https://doi.org/10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9) an effective method to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS). TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation for genome-wide association studies (GWAS) findings. However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, which may overlook more intricate interactions at the network level.

In this manuscript, we aim to address this knowledge gap by proposing a novel approach that projects genetic associations through gene expression patterns, highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms at the network level. This method leverages the power of TWAS and eQTLs data while incorporating gene co-expression networks, enabling the identification of complex interactions among genes implicated in diseases and drug responses. By clustering complex traits and analyzing their genetic underpinnings within these networks, we can uncover novel therapeutic targets and facilitate drug repurposing efforts.

Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) are a class of genetic analysis methods that aim to uncover the relationship between perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms and the association between genetic variants and human diseases ([@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]). These approaches have been successful in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level ([@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]), predicting disease risk (polygenic scores) ([@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w]), and repurposing drugs ([@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]). With the abundance of gene expression data across various tissues ([@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]), TWAS offers an effective means of identifying these biological processes by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for genome-wide association studies (GWAS) findings. Nevertheless, one limitation of TWAS is its focus on individual gene-level analysis, which fails to capture more intricate network-level interactions.

Addressing this knowledge gap, the present study proposes a novel approach that projects genetic associations through gene expression patterns, thereby highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms at the network level. By clustering complex traits ([@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]), this research aims to identify therapeutic targets and facilitate drug repurposing, thereby advancing the field of functional genomics.

---
Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) are a type of genetic analysis that examine whether alterations in gene regulatory mechanisms play a role in the relationship between genetic variants and human diseases ([@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]). These approaches have been successful in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level ([@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]) and have also been applied to disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) ([@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w]) and drug repurposing tasks ([@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]). With the abundance of gene expression data available across various tissues ([@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]), TWAS offers an effective method for identifying these biological processes by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings. However, one limitation of TWAS is that it operates at the individual gene level, which may overlook more intricate interactions at the network level.

In this manuscript, we aim to address this knowledge gap by proposing a novel approach that projects genetic associations through gene expression patterns, highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms. By considering the complex interplay of genes within networks, our method aims to provide a more comprehensive understanding of the relationship between genetic variants and human diseases, ultimately contributing to the advancement of functional genomics research and therapeutic target identification for drug repurposing.

Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has paved the way for novel analytical methods to identify biological processes associated with genetic variants. 

Content: A prominent approach, transcription-wide association studies (TWAS), integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of GWAS findings by testing perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms at the individual gene level [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. This method has proven successful in explaining disease etiology at the transcriptome level and has contributed to disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) and drug repurposing [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433; @doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w; @doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS primarily focuses on individual gene-level interactions and may overlook more complex network-level relationships.

Conclusion: Bridging this knowledge gap requires the development of methods that capture intricate interactions at the network level while maintaining the ability to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings, thereby enhancing our understanding of disease etiology and facilitating advancements in disease-risk prediction and drug repurposing.

A popular method to achieve this is through transcription-wide association studies (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of GWAS findings.

Content: TWAS functions at the individual gene level, thereby overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level. This approach tests whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases, with noteworthy achievements in comprehending disease etiology at the transcriptome level. Moreover, TWAS has contributed to disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) and drug repurposing tasks. However, its reliance on individual gene-based analysis may overlook essential information embedded in gene co-expression patterns.

Conclusion: Bridging this knowledge gap, our study introduces a novel approach that projects genetic associations through gene expression patterns, thereby highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms at the network level. By clustering complex traits and considering gene co-expression, we aim to reveal previously undetected therapeutic targets and facilitate drug repurposing efforts.

Conclusion: Despite TWAS's success in capturing gene-level interactions, there remains a need to address more complex network-level interactions that may contribute to our understanding of the genetic architecture underlying human diseases. This manuscript aims to address this knowledge gap by proposing and validating an extension to the existing TWAS framework.

---
The increasing abundance of gene expression data across various tissues provides an opportunity to identify biological processes effectively [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. One such approach is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation of GWAS findings at the individual gene level. However, TWAS does not capture more complex interactions occurring at the network level. The approach is based on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. TWAS has achieved significant success in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], as well as in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing tasks [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].

---
Context: The increasing accessibility of gene expression data across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9] has opened new avenues for understanding the genetic underpinnings of complex diseases. 

Content: A popular approach to leverage this resource is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings by testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases. This method has been successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing tasks [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS primarily focuses on individual gene level analysis, thereby overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level.

Conclusion: Bridging this knowledge gap, our study introduces a novel approach that projects genetic associations through gene expression patterns to highlight disease etiology and drug mechanisms, focusing on the clustering of complex traits within gene co-expression networks. This strategy goes beyond TWAS limitations by incorporating network-level insights, thereby refining therapeutic targets and facilitating drug repurposing efforts in a more integrated manner.

---
Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has paved the way for novel approaches to identify biological processes associated with human diseases. 

Content: A prominent method, transcription-wide association study (TWAS), integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of GWAS findings by testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and diseases [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. TWAS has been successful in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level and has contributed to disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) and drug repurposing tasks [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433; @doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w; @doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS primarily operates at the individual gene level, overlooking more complex interactions at the network level.

Conclusion: Despite its accomplishments, there is a need to extend TWAS methodologies to capture intricate interactions at the network level, thereby providing a more comprehensive understanding of disease-associated biological processes and human diseases' genetic underpinnings.

Context: The advent of gene expression data across various tissues has paved the way for novel methods to identify biological processes associated with genetic variants [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. Conclusion: Despite these accomplishments, TWAS's reliance on individual gene-based analysis may overlook higher-order interactions within gene networks. This knowledge gap warrants the exploration of alternative methods that capture complex gene co-expression patterns to further elucidate disease etiology and drug mechanisms [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433; @doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w; @doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. The manuscript aims to address this challenge by clustering complex traits and identifying therapeutic targets through functional genomics approaches that consider gene co-expression patterns.

TWAS has been instrumental in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level and has made significant contributions to disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing tasks [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, which may overlook more intricate interactions at the network level.

Conclusion: Bridging this knowledge gap requires addressing complex interactions among genes and their regulatory mechanisms, which could offer a more comprehensive understanding of disease etiology and improved risk prediction, drug repurposing, or therapeutic strategies.

---
The increasing accessibility of gene expression data across various tissues presents an opportunity to identify biological processes effectively [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. A promising approach to achieve this is through transcription-wide association studies (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic understanding of GWAS findings. Nevertheless, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, thereby overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level. TWAS methodologies test whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and such approaches have proven highly successful in several areas. They have enhanced our understanding of disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], improved disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and facilitated drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].

---
Context: The advent of gene expression data across numerous tissues has paved the way for novel methods to identify biological processes associated with human diseases. 

Content: A prominent approach, transcription-wide association studies (TWAS), amalgamates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data with genome-wide association studies (GWAS) findings to offer a mechanistic interpretation at the individual gene level [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. This method has achieved remarkable success in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level, predicting disease risk through polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and repurposing drugs [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS primarily focuses on individual gene-level associations, neglecting more intricate interactions at the network level.

Conclusion: This manuscript aims to address the knowledge gap by proposing a method that projects genetic associations onto gene expression patterns, thereby highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms through the clustering of complex traits [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]. By considering gene co-expression and network-level interactions, the proposed approach intends to enhance our understanding of genetic associations with human diseases and contribute to therapeutic target identification as well as drug repurposing efforts.
